newsitem.title: USA: IBM to acquire Edmark for $80 million in cash.
newsitem.headline: IBM to acquire Edmark for $80 million in cash.

text.p: International Business Machines Corp. said Wednesday it agreed to acquire Edmark Corp., a publisher of children's education software, for $80 million in cash.
The world's largest computer maker said it will shortly launch a tender offer for the shares of Redmond, Wash.-based Edmark at $15.50 per share.
Following the news, Edmark's stock jumped $4.0625 to $15.50 on the Nasdaq market, while IBM was up 37.5 cents at $133.50 on the New York Stock Exchange.

"The merger of Edmark represents the next stage in our strategy of focusing on education and enhanced learning and further strengthens our leadership position in the home consumer marketplace," said Jim Firestone, general manager, IBM Consumer Division.
Edmark makes education software for kindergarten through 12th grade.

"Schools and parents are changing the way they use technology to educate their children," Firestone said. "Increasingly, networks and the Internet will allow parents, teachers and students to work together in new ways."
IBM said the directors and executive officers of Edmark have agreed to sell their shares.
IBM said it plans to operate the unit under the Edmark name in Redmond, with Firestone overseeing and directing operations.
Edmark is the creator of the newly released Mighty Math Series, Sammy's Science House, Stanley's Stickers Stories, and the Thinkin' Things series.
